contentrichtext.text: {{MedalTableTop|name=Greg Foster|medals= {{Medal|Sport | Men's [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]]}} {{Medal|Country | the {{USA}} }} {{Medal|Competition|[[Olympic Games]]}} {{Medal|Silver| [[Athletics at the 1984 Summer Olympics|1984 Los Angeles]] | 110 m hurdles}} {{Medal|Competition|[[IAAF World Championships in Athletics|World Championships]]}} {{Medal|Gold | [[1983 World Championships in Athletics|1983 Helsinki]] | [[1983 World Championships in Athletics - Men's 110 metre hurdles|110 m hurdles]]}} {{Medal|Gold | [[1987 World Championships in Athletics|1987 Rome]] | [[1987 World Championships in Athletics - Men's 110 metre hurdles|110 m hurdles]]}} {{Medal|Gold | [[1991 World Championships in Athletics|1991 Tokyo]] | [[1991 World Championships in Athletics - Men's 110 metre hurdles|110 m hurdles]]}} {{Medal|Competition|[[Goodwill Games]]}} {{Medal|Gold | [[Goodwill Games|1986 Moscow]] | 110 m hurdles}} {{Medal|Competition|[[IAAF World Indoor Championships|World Indoor Championships]]}} {{Medal|Gold |[[1991 IAAF World Indoor Championships|1991 Sevilla]]|60 m hurdles}} }} '''Gregory ("Greg") Foster''' (born August 4, 1958) was an [[United States|American]] [[hurdling]] [[Athletics (sport)|athlete]]. He was born in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. He is the only person in the history of the [[IAAF World Championships in Athletics]] to win three consecutive 110 meter hurdling titles (1983, 1987, and 1991). He was the [[1981 IAAF World Cup]] and the 1991 World Indoor hurdling champion. As well as his international titles, Foster was twice NCAA outdoor champion (1978 and 1980) in the 110 meter hurdles and was the NCAA 200 meter dash champion in 1979. He won 10 U.S. national titles, four of them outdoors in the 110 meter hurdles (1981, 1983, 1986, and 1987) and six indoors, in the 60 yard hurdles (1983, 1984, 1985), 55 meter hurdles (1987, 1988) and 60 meter hurdles (1991). He broke the indoor [[world record]] for the 50 meter hurdles in 1985 (6.35 seconds) and tied that mark in 1987. He also broke the 60 meter hurdle indoor world record in 1987 with a time of 7.36. His personal best time for the 110 meter hurdles was 13.03, run at the [[Weltklasse ZÃ¼rich]] meet in 1981 in which [[Renaldo Nehemiah]] became the first man the break the 13 second barrier, with his 12.93. Foster was ranked in the top ten hurdlers in the world for 15 out of 16 years 1977 to 1992. Five of those years, he was ranked number one, 1982, 1983, 1986, 1987 and 1991.<ref>http://www.trackandfieldnews.com/rankings/men/09-m110HRank.pdf</ref> ==Failed dope test== Foster was suspended from athletics for almost 6 months in 1990 after testing positive for pseudo ephedrine, [[ephedrine]] and [[phenylpropanolamine]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Foster Suspended After Positive Test | url = http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE1D8153BF933A15757C0A966958260&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fSubjects%2fT%2fTrack%20and%20Field | work = The New York Times | date = 1990-04-19 | accessdate = 2007-01-10 }}</ref> ==See also== * [[List of doping cases in athletics]] ==References== <references/> ==External links== *{{iaaf name|880|Greg Foster}} *[http://www.usatf.org/halloffame/tf/showbio.asp?hofids=58/ USATF biography] {{Footer World Champions 110 m hurdles Men}} {{Footer World Indoor Champions 60m Hurdles Men}} {{Footer IAAF World Cup Champions 110m Hurdles Men}} {{Footer USA Track & Field 1984 Summer Olympics}} __NOTOC__ {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Foster, Greg | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American hurdler | DATE OF BIRTH = 1958-08-04 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Chicago, Illinois | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Foster, Greg}} [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American hurdlers]] [[Category:Male hurdlers]] [[Category:American sportspeople in doping cases]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1984 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Doping cases in athletics]] [[Category:Olympic track and field athletes of the United States]] [[Category:People from Chicago, Illinois]] [[Category:Olympic medalists in athletics (track and field)]] [[Category:UCLA Bruins men's track and field athletes]] [[Category:World Championships in Athletics medalists]] {{US-hurdles-athletics-bio-stub}}
